data.title: I Lived with You (1933)
data.meta_description: In London a young lady meets a homeless and apparently penniless Russian prince. She introduces him to her middle-class Fulham family and he moves in. It turns out he still has a number of diamonds given him by the last czar, and he is persuaded to start selling them. The resulting money, and his princely notoriety, soon cause changes in everyone's lives.
data.text:
The chaotic energy of Russian decadent carousing in furnished rooms can be seen here, almost as it was in the pre-revolutionary years. Of course, this is a farce and a parody, but it is harmless, kind, and even a little respectful. The Parisian dream of Russian romance on the outskirts of London is clear to Prince Felix. It's also clear who the Prince's prototype is. //"Боже мой! Проклятaя женщина!" God. That accent is out of this world. // Novello is infinitely beautiful: a rambunctious homeless child from a faraway land who brought a holiday with him to his new home and family. He is more Russian than any other Russian (well, Anton Walbrook can fight him). In such a sweet…

This review was originally written for the Early May 2020 edition of Talking Pictures TV Podcast.

I host a podcast on Russian films and films with a Russian connection called A Russian & Soviet Movie Podcast, so when I saw that the main character I Lived With You is a Russian emigre prince, I couldn't help but be intrigued.

We don't meet him for a few minutes though, with the film instead introducing us to three members of the Wallis family, Will, who works at a London jewellers, and his two adult daughters, Gladys and Ada. It is Gladys who is surprised to discover a shabbily-dressed man lounging on a bench in Hampton Court Palace maze. The man introduces himself as…
